@Tracey Bristow: For those of you looking to perform a downmix of your 5.1 copy, I'll give you my settings which I used (in Sound Forge but you can enter these values in any decent audio editing program with an AC3 decoder):Channel 1: -4.4dB leftChannel 2 (centre): -4.4dB left, -4.4dB rightChannel 3: -4.4dB rightChannel 4: (no audio in this channel so 0% for both channels)Channel 5: -7.9dB leftChannel 6: -7.9dB rightI found these settings gave me the ideal dynamic range whilst maintaining the balance between the two channels as DT intended.Be careful as some software misinterpret the centre channel as being channel 3, as was the case with the default presets in my Sound Forge program. A bit of a blunder on their part but you'll know the centre channel when you see the waveform in comparison to the others anyway, let alone hear the equally obvious difference.

For those of you looking to perform a downmix of your 5.1 copy, I'll give you my settings which I used (in Sound Forge but you can enter these values in any decent audio editing program with an AC3 decoder):Channel 1: -4.4dB leftChannel 2 (centre): -4.4dB left, -4.4dB rightChannel 3: -4.4dB rightChannel 4: (no audio in this channel so 0% for both channels)Channel 5: -7.9dB leftChannel 6: -7.9dB rightI found these settings gave me the ideal dynamic range whilst maintaining the balance between the two channels as DT intended.Be careful as some software misinterpret the centre channel as being channel 3, as was the case with the default presets in my Sound Forge program. A bit of a blunder on their part but you'll know the centre channel when you see the waveform in comparison to the others anyway, let alone hear the equally obvious difference.

I notice a distinct difference in dynamic range when comparing the samples on HDTracks vs. my officially purchased MP3 copy. The difference is not due to 96k/24-bit vs. 44.1k/16-bit, but instead to a different master produced for HDTracks. Dynamic range compression and brick-wall limiting have nothing to do with sample and/or bit rate. 44.1k/16-bit should still be sufficient for masters and was chosen wisely by the CD-ROM RedBook design team. I will grant that 24 bits of sample depth will significantly lower the noise floor, but that was never a problem for the 16 bit depth to begin with, at least not for a final master.

Mangini has definitely put his stamp on this album, although I found his drumming and overall compositional choices to be somewhat lacking the same dynamics that Portnoy brought to the mix. I kept having the impression that I was listening to a highly skilled and technically proficient session drummer who was showing moments of brilliance but with a certain clinical restraint. Still an amazing drummer though and one of my all time favorites. As for LaBrie... his voice sounded tired on this album and after a while I actually found myself looking forward to the instrumental sections. Myung was simply amazing on this album and I think this is one of his best works to date. As for Petrucci... his guitar work blew me away this time around, although there was a moment here and there where I felt he overplayed some of his solos. Yet even when he went a little too far in some sections he always managed to reign in the notes with absolute class. That's what makes him my all time favorite guitarist! Rudess was also a class act and his playing was close behind Petrucci in terms of technical skill and wizardry, although I feel Jordan overplayed quite a bit with his solos in some areas... times when I wish he would just tone it down and launch into something more thematic or melodic, Kevin Moore style. I didn't like the way the introduction (Track 1) ended with a finale, even before the first song got underway. I was expecting it to seamlessly bridge into the second track. As a DT fan since 1990 I personally felt the highlights of the album were 'False Awakening Suite', 'Enigma Machine', 'Behind The Veil' and 'Illumination Theory'. The rest of the album was below average for me compared to their last effort, but with some airtime I'm sure some of the tracks will grow on me. Overall I gave this album an 8/10.
